author: Erika Wurst
title: Man in gunfight with deputies tied to second Tucson shooting
text:
A man jailed in connection with a shootout earlier this month in which he and two deputies were wounded has been linked to a separate shooting days before.
Meanwhile, one of of the two wounded deputies has been released from the hospital.
Jordyn Guadalupe Sanchez, 29, is being held at the Pima County jailâ€™s medical unit for wounds he sustained in the gunfight with deputies .
Sanchez faces 13 felony counts, including two counts of attempted first degree murder, endangerment of a child and discharging a weapon into a residential structure, according to a Pima County Sheriffâ€™s Department news release.
Sanchez is being held without bond and is expected to be in court Friday for a hearing, records show.
 A list of places that will be open on Christmas Day 2023 Rainy day in Tucson sets record, storm to be gone by Christmas Eve Meet the Tucson man who saved Barbie You have 72 hours in Tucson. Here's what you should do. Five Tucson Unified 'D' schools struggle to fill teaching jobs 46 fun events happening in Tucson this weekend Dec. 28-31 ðŸŒ®ðŸŽ¶ Embattled Tucson Arizona, California, Nevada near long-term deal to use less Colorado River water The two deputies were shot while answering a domestic violence call about 7:15 p.m. Dec. 21, at a house in the 9000 block of North Kanawha Street, near North Shannon and West Overton roads.
Deputies were called to the home when an â€œerraticâ€ Sanchez showed up wanting to take his three non-custodial children from the residence, according to a complaint filed in Pima County Justice Court.
Gunfire erupted soon after the deputies made contact with Sanchez at the house, the department has said. A scuffle led to both deputies, and Sanchez being shot.
On Saturday, Deputy Leonardo Wells, one of the wounded deputies, headed home from the hospital, although not on his own two feet.
A white cast covered his left leg from foot to upper thigh.
As he was rolled through a door in a wheelchair and into a hospital lobby filled with familiar faces, the claps rolled like thunder, a video of his release shows.
The clapping continued, all the out the front door, and didnâ€™t end until Wells was safely in a vehicle for the ride home with his family.
The second injured officer has not been publicly identified and remained hospitalized Wednesday.
The shooting was the second allegedly involving Sanchez in the days leading up to the Christmas holiday, deputies said.
During a search of Sanchezâ€™s home following the shootout, deputies found evidence that linked him to a Dec. 16 shooting at a smoke Shop, in the 900 block of East Fort Lowell Road.
In that incident, an employee told deputies that Sanchez seemed fine when he entered the shop, but became upset for an unknown reason, a court complaint says.
Sanchez used a racial slur against someone inside the shop and a shoving match ensued. Someone inside the shop pulled a knife on Sanchez to hold him at bay, but he pulled out a pistol and shot the man in the thigh before running away, the complaint says.
Sanchez admitted to his involvement in the smoke shop incident, and the casings found at the smoke shop matched the casings found at the deputy shooting scene, according to the complaint.
Cruz has prior convictions for burglary, narcotics possession and for possessing a weapon as a felon, according to court records.

author: Jeremy Brener
title: What will Steelers QB room look like in 2024?
text: The [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://www.behindthesteelcurtain.com/) know one thing about their quarterbacks going into the offseason: change is needed. Whether the change is small, like finding a new rookie on Day 3 in the draft, or large, like trading for Russell Wilson, things will inevitably look different in 2024. [Spotracâ€™s Michael Ginnitti](https://www.spotrac.com/news/predicting-quarterback-resolutions-for-2024-2104/) suggested a solution for all quarterback rooms for the 2024 season, including the Steelers. Kenny Pickett carries a fully guaranteed 2 years, $4.6M, and should regain his starting gig next Spring. 2024 will be a pivotal year for the future of Pickett in Pitt. Mitchell Trubisky holds a non-guaranteed 2 years, $11.25M (incredibly). THE STEELERS RELEASE TRUBISKY BEFORE HIS $1M ROSTER BONUS IS DUE NEXT MARCH, RE-SIGNING MASON RUDOLPH TO A 1 YEAR, $2.5M CONTRACT TO BACKUP PICKETT. If Pickett and Rudolph were to return, it will likely give the Steelers reason to select a quarterback late in the draft this spring or sign an undrafted player. As weâ€™ve learned this season, there is no such thing as too much quarterback depth, and the Steelers need to find some new blood to shake things up for next season.

author: Elena Genillo
title: Una alerta roja que hizo temer lo peor en Huelva
text: DANA Una alerta roja que hizo temer lo peor en Huelva En Cartaya cayeron 117 litros en tres horas y un tornado atemorizÃ³ Isla Cristina Los habitantes de las comarcas del AndÃ©valo, el Condado y el Litoral Litoral pasaron la madrugada de ayer con la respiraciÃ³n contenida tras lo sucedido en la Comunidad Valenciana. A eso de las cinco de la madrugada, el avance del temporal obligÃ³ a la Agencia Estatal de MeteorologÃ­a (AEMET) a activar la alerta roja por riesgo de lluvias torrenciales en estas tres comarcas onubenses. La fuerte tormenta y la forma en la que caÃ­a el agua, de forma torrencial, despertÃ³ a muchos de los vecinos, que se levantaron de sus camas para captar las impactantes imÃ¡genes de los rayos iluminando el cielo y las calles inundadas. El propio presidente de la Junta de AndalucÃ­a, Juanma Moreno, pedÃ­a ya amanecido el dÃ­a a travÃ©s de sus redes Â«extremar la precauciÃ³nÂ» y, sobre todo, evitar los desplazamientos innecesarios. La alerta roja se dio por finalizada a las tres de la tarde, con registros de hasta 117 litros por metro cuadrado que cayeron en solo tres horas en el municipio de Cartaya. TambiÃ©n se registraron precipitaciones de similar intensidad en El Aljaraque, GibraleÃ³n y Punta UmbrÃ­a. En el Aljaraque, de hecho, los bomberos realizaron una de las maniobras mÃ¡s espectaculares de la jornada, al rescatar de madrugada a una mujer que se refugiÃ³ en el tejado de su vivienda al ver cÃ³mo iba creciendo el nivel del agua. MÃ¡s espectaculares aÃºn fueron las imÃ¡genes del tornado que sacudiÃ³ Isla Cristina y que provocÃ³ dos heridos, uno de ellos al derrumbarse el techo de la piscina municipal y clavarse algunos cristales. TambiÃ©n en la madrugada del jueves se temiÃ³ por un grupo de 20 niÃ±os aislados en una casa de campo de Punta UmbrÃ­a al estar el camino de acceso intransitable. Una incidencia que fue resuelta por la maÃ±ana. Ya por la tarde, la AEMET degradÃ³ la alerta por lluvias a naranja, nivel de riesgo en el que permaneciÃ³ todo el territorio onubense hasta la medianoche del viernes. SegÃºn los datos ofrecidos por el Servicio de Emergencias 112 de AndalucÃ­a, en la jornada de ayer se atendieron mÃ¡s de 117 incidencias, principalmente por anegaciones en sÃ³tanos, viviendas de planta baja y establecimientos. AdemÃ¡s de en los mencionados municipios, el 112 tuvo que actÃºar tambiÃ©n en otros como El Cerro del AndÃ©valo, La Nava, Lepe, Lucena Del Puerto, Palos de La Frontera y Ayamonte. De hecho, en la aldea almonteÃ±a de El RocÃ­o se tuvieron que cortar varios accesos y dos de sus calles al quedar Â«totalmente intransitablesÂ» por el paso de la DANA en Huelva, segÃºn infomÃ³ la PolicÃ­a Local. Una de las consecuencias que mÃ¡s preocupaba del paso de la DANA por Huelva era la crecida del rÃ­o Oraque, tributario del Odiel, despuÃ©s de que fruto del temporal de fuertes precipitaciones alcanzase su Â«mÃ¡ximo nivel histÃ³ricoÂ» desencadenando una situaciÃ³n de peligro, segÃºn informÃ³ ayer el consejero de Presidencia e Interior, Antonio Sanz. Afortunadamente, durante la jornada se fue reduciendo el caudal de dicho rÃ­o, sin que finalmente fuera necesario acometer desalojos preventivos entre los vecinos. Jerez se recupera del susto MÃ¡s de 200 vecinos de barriadas rurales de Jerez, concretamente de Las Pachecas, La Greduela, El Portal y La Corta, tuvieron que pasar la noche del jueves en distintas instalaciones cedidas por la Junta de AndalucÃ­a, o en casas de familiares, a modo de prevenciÃ³n por la subida del rÃ­o Guadalete. Las fuertes lluvias de los Ãºltimos dÃ­as, que dejaron mÃ¡s de 160 litros por metro cuadrado durante las jornadas del miÃ©rcoles y el jueves , llevaron a la Junta a activar el Plan de Emergencias por riesgo de inundaciones, llevando a desalojar a 211 vecinos de las cuatro barriadas rurales citadas, situadas muy cerca de la ribera del Guadalete. Ya en la maÃ±ana del viernes, el presidente de la Junta de AndalucÃ­a, Juanma Moreno, anunciÃ³ a sociales, que los 211 vecinos desalojados podÃ­an volver a sus casas. El caudal del rÃ­o alcanzÃ³ su mÃ¡ximo histÃ³rico a las ocho de la maÃ±ana del viernes, con 5,43 metros de altura, y comenzÃ³ a bajar a partir de las nueve de la maÃ±ana. Â«Mantenemos activada la fase de emergencia, situaciÃ³n operativa 1, por la previsiÃ³n de intensas lluvias. Prudencia y gracias a todos por la colaboraciÃ³nÂ», escribiÃ³ el presidente andaluz. Pasividad ante la tragedia

author: Semana
title: El problema de salud que podrÃ­a sufrir si duerme con el televisor prendido toda la noche
text: Son varios los efectos negativos que puede tener el dormir con el televisor encendido toda la noche. Estos son algunos de ellos: AlteraciÃ³n del sueÃ±o : La luz azul emitida por el televisor puede inhibir la producciÃ³n de melatonina, una hormona clave para regular el sueÃ±o. Esto puede dificultar la conciliaciÃ³n del sueÃ±o y alterar la calidad del mismo, causando despertares frecuentes o un sueÃ±o superficial. Fatiga y somnolencia diurna : La mala calidad del sueÃ±o puede llevar a una sensaciÃ³n de cansancio constante durante el dÃ­a, lo que afecta la concentraciÃ³n, el rendimiento en el trabajo o estudios, y aumenta el riesgo de accidentes. Aumento del estrÃ©s : La exposiciÃ³n continua a la luz y el ruido del televisor durante la noche puede elevar los niveles de cortisol, la hormona del estrÃ©s. Esto puede contribuir a un aumento de la tensiÃ³n y la ansiedad. Problemas de salud mental : La falta de un sueÃ±o reparador y el estrÃ©s acumulado pueden contribuir a problemas de salud mental, como la depresiÃ³n y la ansiedad. Riesgo de obesidad : La falta de sueÃ±o estÃ¡ relacionada con el aumento de peso. La privaciÃ³n del sueÃ±o afecta las hormonas que regulan el apetito, lo que puede llevar a comer en exceso y, eventualmente, a la obesidad. Problemas cardiovasculares : La privaciÃ³n crÃ³nica del sueÃ±o puede aumentar el riesgo de enfermedades cardÃ­acas, presiÃ³n arterial alta y otros problemas cardiovasculares.InvestigaciÃ³n revelÃ³ que la falta de sueÃ±o anula los resultados de la actividad fÃ­sica diariaPara mantener un estilo de vida saludable, el ejercicio es una parte fundamental. Sea cual sea el tipo de rutina o tiempo dispuesto, realizar actividad fÃ­sica es importante junto con la alimentaciÃ³n. Sin embargo, malos hÃ¡bitos como la falta de sueÃ±o imposibilitan sacarle el mÃ¡ximo provecho.La cantidad de horas de sueÃ±o son importantes para ver los resultados del ejercicio. A simple vista no tienen relaciÃ³n alguna, pero una reciente investigaciÃ³n encontrÃ³ la relevancia entre ambos asuntos, concretamente con el funcionamiento correcto del cerebro.El estudio Asociaciones conjuntas de la actividad fÃ­sica y la duraciÃ³n del sueÃ±o con el envejecimiento cognitivo: anÃ¡lisis longitudinal de un estudio de cohorte inglÃ©s, publicado por Lancet Healthy Longevity, indica que las personas con actividad fÃ­sica frecuente y en especial con mayor intensidad, pero descansando menos de seis horas en las noches, presentaban un deterioro cognitivo considerable en contraste con las personas que se ejercitaban en menor nivel pero con un descanso balanceado. â€œ Nuestro estudio sugiere que puede ser necesario dormir lo suficiente para obtener todos los beneficios cognitivos de la actividad fÃ­sica â€, explicÃ³ la Dra. Mikaela Bloomberg, autora principal de la investigaciÃ³n, al seÃ±alar que los resultados encontrados demuestran que el sueÃ±o y el ejercicio van de la mano.

author: @le_parisien
title: Liban : Â« refuser Â» un cessez-le-feu serait une Â« faute Â» du Premier ministre israÃ©lien, assure Emmanuel Macron
text:
Liban : Â« refuser Â» un cessez-le-feu serait une Â« faute Â» du Premier ministre israÃ©lien, assure Emmanuel Macron
Â« La proposition qui a Ã©tÃ© faite est une proposition solide. Elle nâ€™a pas Ã©tÃ© faite en lâ€™air Â», a assurÃ© Emmanuel Macron, lors dâ€™une confÃ©rence de presse au Canada.
Le prÃ©sident franÃ§ais, Emmanuel Macron, a estimÃ© jeudi que ce serait Â« une faute Â» de la part du Premier ministre israÃ©lien, Benyamin Netanyahou, de refuser le cessez-le-feu proposÃ© au Liban et quâ€™il prendrait la Â« responsabilitÃ© Â» dâ€™une escalade rÃ©gionale, alors quâ€™IsraÃ«l a poursuivi les frappes ce jeudi, tuant des dizaines de personnes.
Â« La proposition qui a Ã©tÃ© faite est une proposition solide. Elle nâ€™a pas Ã©tÃ© faite en lâ€™air Â», a-t-il dit lors dâ€™une confÃ©rence de presse Ã  MontrÃ©al avec le Premier ministre canadien, Justin Trudeau. Elle a Ã©tÃ© Â« prÃ©parÃ©e, nÃ©gociÃ©e avec le Premier ministre Netanyahou et ses Ã©quipes, Ã  la fois par les AmÃ©ricains et par nous-mÃªmes Â», a-t-il soulignÃ©. La France sâ€™oppose Ã  ce que le Liban Â« devienne un nouveau Gaza Â», a prÃ©venu le prÃ©sident franÃ§ais.
Â« Je pense que ce serait une faute de la part du Premier ministre (israÃ©lien) de la refuser parce quâ€™il prendrait la responsabilitÃ© dâ€™une escalade rÃ©gionale, Ã©videmment de nouvelles victimes civiles au Liban, mais une escalade bien au-delÃ , que nul ne maÃ®triserait Â», a-t-il martelÃ©. Â« Il faut absolument parvenir Ã  un cessez-le-feu immÃ©diatement Â», a renchÃ©ri le Premier ministre canadien, parlant Â« dâ€™images horribles Â».
Des centaines de personnes dÃ©cÃ©dÃ©es dans les frappes
Les Ã‰tats-Unis, lâ€™Union europÃ©enne et dâ€™autres alliÃ©s, ainsi que plusieurs Ã‰tats arabes, ont lancÃ© un appel commun en faveur dâ€™un arrÃªt des combats au Liban pendant 21 jours, aprÃ¨s que les frappes aÃ©riennes israÃ©liennes ont tuÃ© des centaines de personnes et dÃ©placÃ© des dizaines de milliers dâ€™autres au Liban cette semaine.
Lâ€™appel Ã  un cessez-le-feu de trois semaines a Ã©tÃ© lancÃ© quelques heures aprÃ¨s que le chef de lâ€™armÃ©e israÃ©lienne, le lieutenant-gÃ©nÃ©ral Herzi Halevi, a demandÃ© mercredi aux soldats de se prÃ©parer Ã  une Ã©ventuelle offensive terrestre contre le Hezbollah. Le prÃ©sident franÃ§ais a estimÃ© que les premiÃ¨res rÃ©actions dâ€™IsraÃ«l Ã  la proposition nâ€™Ã©taient pas Â« dÃ©finitives Â» et Ã©voquÃ© la possibilitÃ© de convoquer un nouveau Conseil de sÃ©curitÃ© sur le sujet pour Â« accroÃ®tre la pression Â».

author: Zane McNeill
title: Ohio Overrides Governorâ€™s Veto, Enacts Gender-Affirming Health Care Ban | Truthout
text:
Israel Famine Expert: Israelâ€™s Starvation of Gaza Has No Parallel in Modern Times Elections States Weigh Bills to Stop Armed Intimidation of Voters and Election Officials Joe Biden Biden Urges House to Approve Bill With $14B to Israel and Cuts to UNRWA Funding Elections Indonesian Defense Minister Declares Electoral Victory Ahead of Official Results More About Donate Manage Your Donation More Ways to Give Subscribe Submission Guidelines Financial Information Privacy Policy Memorial Essay Prize Truthout Center for Grassroots Journalism Job Openings Contact Us Â© 2024 Truthout News | LGBTQ Rights Ohio Overrides Governorâ€™s Veto, Enacts Gender-Affirming Health Care Ban â€œWe really did do everything we could,â€ one transgender activist in Ohio said.
By Zane McNeill , T ruthout Published January 25, 2024 A transgender rights advocate holds a sign outside the Ohio Statehouse during a rally in Columbus, Ohio, on June 24, 2021. Stephen Zenner / SOPA Images / LightRocket via Getty Images On Wednesday, the Ohio legislature overrode Gov. Mike DeWineâ€™s (R) veto of a bill that bans gender-affirming care for transgender youth and restricts trans athletes from participating on school sports teams. The anti-trans law will go into effect in 90 days.
â€œThis state-sponsored vendetta against some of Ohioâ€™s most vulnerable young people is beyond cruel. We stand in solidarity with all trans youth,â€ the ACLU of Ohio said on social media .
Earlier this month, DeWine vetoed the bill, saying , â€œParents have looked me in the eye and told me that but for this treatment, their child would be dead.â€ However, in an attempt to persuade right-wing lawmakers not to override his veto, DeWine introduced dangerous administrative rules that would restrict gender-affirming care for transgender patients of all ages.
â€œThe restrictions would prohibit most primary care providers from providing hormone treatments to transgender people of any age, enforce a list of cumbersome requirements unfounded by medical evidence, and threaten to shut down care across the state,â€ the ACLU of Ohio said in a statement .
Related Story News | LGBTQ Rights Ohio House Overrides Governor DeWineâ€™s Veto of Anti-Trans Bill â€œItâ€™s despicable,â€ a transgender advocate in Ohio told Truthout. By Zane McNeill , T ruthout January 11, 2024 Truthout Despite DeWine attempting to placate conservative lawmakers with these sweeping new rules , the Ohio House ended vacation early and voted 65-28 to override DeWineâ€™s veto. The Senateâ€™s 23-9 vote on Wednesday to override DeWineâ€™s veto makes Ohio the 23rd state to restrict gender-affirming care for transgender minors and the 24th state to restrict trans girls and women from playing on womenâ€™s sports teams.
â€œWe really did do everything we could,â€ said Cam Ogden , a transgender advocate in the state who organized against the anti-trans bill. â€œIâ€™m so damn tired.â€
This veto override does not affect the administrative rules introduced by DeWineâ€™s administration, which are still moving forward .
â€œTo make matters worse, Ohio is considering adopting sweeping new rules that would restrict the care that Ohio providers can provide to all transgender patients of ALL ages,â€ the ACLU of Ohio said . â€œThese restrictions, if finalized, would make Ohio the most restrictive state in the U.S. with respect to evidence-based health care.â€
Within the last 72 hours, TransOhio, a transgender advocacy group in the state, has received requests for emergency funds from more than 68 families fleeing the state because of the enactment of the anti-trans law. The organization is requesting donations to help supply the emergency fund.
â€œTheir government is forcing them to uproot their lives,â€ Dara Adkison, secretary of the board for TransOhio, told NBC News . â€œTheyâ€™re selling their homes, theyâ€™re changing jobs and careers and closing out all of their savings. Theyâ€™re closing their businesses, theyâ€™re leaving their medical practices. The intense amount of personal and community trauma that is being inflicted by the government right now and putting these families through who just love their fâ€”ing kids is so cruel.â€
Since the start of the year, state lawmakers have introduced more than 350 anti-LGBTQ bills across the country.
â€œThe right is appearing to shift to targeting adults and all queer people. As we have said time and time again, this was never about protecting kids,â€ LGBTQ+ legislative researcher Allison Chapman said on social media . â€œThis is a part of a highly organized, heavily funded initiative to force queer people back into the closet.â€

author: Eric Lagatta
title: 2024 total solar eclipse: Date, path, map, how to watch it
text: 2024 brings a rare solar eclipse that won't happen again for decades: Here's what to know On April 8, a total solar eclipse will travel from Texas to Maine, shrouding the U.S. in darkness. It's the first since 2017, and your last chance to see one for 20 years. [Eric Lagatta](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/5803430002/eric-lagatta/) In only a matter of three months, tens of millions of people across the continent will be able to step outside their doors and [witness a rare celestial event](/story/news/nation/2023/04/06/total-solar-eclipse-april-2024/11609882002/) that hasn't occurred in years. About 20 million people were able to experience the total eclipse of Aug. 21, 2017 as it traveled along a path from Oregon to South Carolina. But when afternoon suddenly looks like nighttime once again in April, the darkness spreading across North America will last for even longer and will potentially be viewed by even more people, the Great American Eclipse website [estimates](https://www.greatamericaneclipse.com/april-8-2024). And you may want to make sure you're one of them. [According to NASA](https://science.nasa.gov/eclipses/future-eclipses/eclipse-2024/), it will be 20 years before another total solar eclipse, when the moon passes between part of the Earth and the sun, temporarily blocks its light. Here's what to know about this spectacular event and how you can prepare to see it as it passes over Mexico, the United States and Canada: Recapping 2023's wild year in space: [UFOs, commercial spaceflight, rogue tomatoes and more](/story/news/nation/2023/12/31/aliens-nasa-commercial-spaceflight-top-space-stories-of-2023/71982253007/) When is the total solar eclipse? The eclipse is set to occur over North America on April 8, 2024. What is a total solar eclipse? Any celestial object like a moon or a planet that passes between two other bodies can create [an eclipse](https://www.nasa.gov/learning-resources/for-kids-and-students/what-is-an-eclipse-grades-5-8/) by obscuring the view of objects like the sun. In the event of a solar eclipse, the moon comes in between the Earth and the sun, blocking its light from reaching a small part of our planet. Partial eclipses, when some part of the sun remains visible, are the most common, making total eclipses a rare sight to behold. Total eclipses can lead to a period of darkness lasting for several minutes, during which time nocturnal animals stir while confused birds and insects may fall silent, NASA says. When a solar eclipse reaches totality, people are able to see the sunâ€™s outer atmosphere called the corona, which is usually obscured by the sun's bright surface. This offers scientists an uncommon opportunity [to study the corona](/story/news/nation/2023/10/13/why-eclipses-fascinate-people/71118439007/). Where can I see the eclipse in April? On April 8, the moonâ€™s shadow will arc across the Pacific, traversing North America and ending at sunset not far from Spain. In the United States alone, 31 million people already live inside the path of totality, according to the Great American Eclipse. Of course, that figure doesn't even account for the tourists sure to flock from all over for a chance to be there when darkness falls. Mexico's pacific coast will be the first location in continental North America to experience totality, which will occur at about 11:07 a.m. PDT, [according to NASA](https://science.nasa.gov/eclipses/future-eclipses/eclipse-2024/where-when/). As the moon's shadow travels northeast, totality in the U.S. will begin in Texas at 1:27 p.m. CDT. The path will cut diagonally across the country, traveling through Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, New York, Vermont and New Hampshire. In the United States, the eclipse's path will end in Maine at 3:35 p.m. EDT before visiting the maritime provinces of Canada, according to estimates. The longest duration will be near Torreon in Mexico at 4 minutes and 27 seconds, almost double that of 2017, according to the Great American Eclipse. Here are some major cities inside the path: - Mazatlan, Sinaloa (Mexico) - Torreon, Coahuila (Mexico) - San Antonio - Austin, Texas - Dallas - Fort Worth, Texas - Indianapolis - Cleveland - Buffalo, New York - Rochester, New York - Syracuse, New York - Montreal, QuÃ©bec (Canada) How is the 2024 eclipse different from the one in 2023? It was just a few months ago that [another type of eclipse](/story/news/nation/2023/10/10/what-time-is-solar-eclipse-saturday/71130701007/) passed over the United States. But when the moon passed between the sun and the Earth in October, it wasn't close enough in its orbit of our planet to completely block out the sun's light. Instead, the moon appeared as a smaller disk in front of the sun, creating a bright halo of light exposed around its edges commonly known as a "ring of fire." The annular solar eclipse [didn't usher in darkness](/story/news/nation/2023/10/14/solar-eclipse-2023-photos/71185631007/) such as [what will occur in April](/story/news/nation/2023/10/10/october-2023-eclipse-map-time-and-location/70902457007/), but it still attracted plenty of stargazers all the same as it was the last of its kind until 2039. How to safely view the eclipse The sun's powerful rays can burn the eyes and damage the retinas of those [who don't wear proper eye protection](/story/money/shopping/2023/10/11/find-solar-eclipse-glasses/71140189007/) or take other safety precautions to view solar eclipses. Even viewing any part of the bright sun through camera lenses, binoculars and telescopes without a specialized solar filter will instantly cause severe eye injury. That's why NASA [advises spectators](https://science.nasa.gov/eclipses/safety/) to plan accordingly and ensure they have the safe â€“ and simple â€“ equipment [needed for solar viewing](/story/news/nation/2023/10/10/safely-watch-solar-eclipse-saturday/70921671007/). Solar eclipse glasses aren't your run-of-the-mill sunglasses: certified eyewear is held to an international safety standard and is 100,000 times darker to block nearly all visible, infrared and ultraviolet light. To make it easy, the American Astronomical Society maintains [a curated list of approved vendors](https://eclipse.aas.org/resources/solar-filters). Another simple method is to create your own pinhole projector to project the sun onto a nearby surface. The American Astronomical Society helpfully offers [instructions](https://eclipse.aas.org/eye-safety/projection) to set them up. However, a total solar eclipse offers spectators a unique opportunity to momentarily remove their eyewear when it's safe. Once the moon blocks the sun's face and the sky turns dark, leaving only the solar corona visible, viewers can take off eclipse glasses or viewers to fully take in the dazzling celestial display. Eric Lagatta covers breaking and trending news for USA TODAY. Reach him at elagatta@gannett.com

author: Ana Tortell
title: Roberta Metsola Is â€˜Very Proudâ€™ That EP Is â€˜First Institutionâ€™ To Urge For A Permanent Ceasefire In Gaza
text:
Roberta Metsola Is â€˜Very Proudâ€™ That EP Is â€˜First Institutionâ€™ To Urge For A Permanent Ceasefire In Gaza
President of the European Parliament (EP) Roberta Metsola stated that she is â€œvery proudâ€ that the EP has become the first institution to call for a permanent ceasefire in Gaza.
â€œThis is a necessary step on the path to lasting peace and stability in the form of a two-state solution,â€ Metsola told Lovin Malta.
Yesterday, MEPs successfully voted for a
resolution that called for a permanent ceasefire in Gaza on two conditions: that Hamas is dismantled and all hostages are released.
PN MEP David Casa voted in favour while PL MEPs Cyrus Engerer and Alex Agius Saliba voted against because they maintain that such a ceasefire should be unconditional.
MEPs Alfred Sant and Josianne Cutajar were not present for the vote.
Metsola explained that this resolution serves as a â€œnecessary step on the path to lasting peace and stability in the form of a two-state solutionâ€.
â€œWe hope others will follow our push in finding a way forward that gives a real perspective to the Palestinian people and security for those in Israel.â€
Metsola went on to reiterate the call for the release of hostages taken during the â€œvile terrorist attackâ€ by Hamas on 7th October and insisted that the group should not play a role in the future of Gaza â€“ â€œthat role must return to legitimate Palestinian leadershipâ€.
â€œThe European Union will also continue to do all it can to ensure that necessary humanitarian aid reaches those in need, that international law is respected, and that accountability for any breaches exists. We will keep engaging with nations in the region to push the path of de-escalation.â€
â€œThe resolution also talks about the need to address the situation in the West Bank and specifically how the EU can address illegal settlements and settler violence there.â€
â€œEven in the fog of war, the EU will keep talking about peace and about the day after. We are ready to help with the transition and rebuilding of the political perspective to peace.â€
Metsola didnâ€™t provide the newsroom with a comment regarding the MEPsâ€™ reasoning to vote against the resolution.
This action was co-financed by the European Union in the frame of the European Parliamentâ€™s grant programme in the field of communication. The European Parliament was not involved in its preparation and is, in no case, responsible for or bound by the information or opinions expressed in the context of this action. In accordance with applicable law, the authors, interviewed people, publishers or programme broadcasters are solely responsible. The European Parliament can also not be held liable for direct or indirect damage that may result from the implementation of the action.
Do you think that this resolution is sufficient?

title: Volta a FranÃ§a de 2027 comeÃ§a em Edimburgo e passa por Inglaterra e PaÃ­s de Gales | MAISFUTEBOL
text:
A Volta a FranÃ§a de 2027 vai partir de Edimburgo, com trÃªs etapas na EscÃ³cia, Inglaterra e PaÃ­s de Gales antes chegar a FranÃ§a, anunciou esta quarta-feira a organizaÃ§Ã£o da emblemÃ¡tica competiÃ§Ã£o gaulesa.
Vinte anos depois de sair de Londres, e de partir de Yorkshire em 2014, o Tour volta ao Reino Unido, que tambÃ©m acolherÃ¡, em localidade a definir, a Grand DÃ©part da corrida feminina, anunciou a Amaury Sports Organisation em conferÃªncia de imprensa na capital escocesa.
Â«O sucesso popular [das anteriores partidas] foi absolutamente fenomenal. EncontrÃ¡mos multidÃµes de genteÂ», declarou o diretor da corrida, Christian Prudhomme, Ã  agÃªncia noticiosa AFP.
A autorizaÃ§Ã£o da UniÃ£o Ciclista Internacional (UCI) que permite aos organizadores colocarem a partida mais distante de FranÃ§a, de quatro em quatro anos, permitirÃ¡ sair de Edimburgo, depois de Copenhaga em 2022.
Os detalhes das etapas e restantes cidades serÃ£o revelados posteriormente, ficando desde jÃ¡ revelado que Â«as colinas e subidas Ã­ngremesÂ» no PaÃ­s de Gales permitirÃ£o colocar Â«ombro a ombro os candidatos Ã  geral finalÂ».
Depois da partida numa sexta-feira, a segunda-feira seguinte, 5 de julho, serÃ¡ um dia de descanso, para o pelotÃ£o se mudar para FranÃ§a para o resto da competiÃ§Ã£o.
Esta serÃ¡ a quinta partida estrangeira em seis anos, depois de Copenhaga (2022), Bilbau (2023), FlorenÃ§a (2024) e Barcelona (2026), com esta ediÃ§Ã£o, que sai de Lille, como Ãºnico Grand DÃ©part nacional.
Estes eventos ajudam Ã  Â«influÃªnciaÂ» da Volta a FranÃ§a, mas trazem um impacto financeiro significativo para a organizaÃ§Ã£o, que estima em seis milhÃµes de euros as receitas de Bilbau e FlorenÃ§a.
